urn:contentItem:5WKD-G671-DYTH-G4NM-00000-00BRENT HARRIS ON FACEBOOK'S APPROACH TO CONTENT OVERSIGHT2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:26:37ZLexisNexisBRENT HARRIS ON FACEBOOK'S APPROACH TO CONTENT OVERSIGHTStates News ServiceLONDON

The following information was released by Chatham House:

Facebook's director of global affairs speaks to Thomas Farrar about the launch of the company's oversight board, competition and government regulation.

Earlier this year, Facebook presented its plans to create an 'oversight board for content decisions'. According to its draft charter, the purpose of this body will be to determine how content should be governed and enforced on the platform. Brent you have been involved in the initial phases of the board could you tell us more about the strategy and why your company feels it must look beyond its internal structures to curate online content?

The goal of the board is to extend decision making beyond the company itself and beyond Silicon Valley and hear from a wide array of people, voices and experts who stand beyond those we usually talk to.

In the last six months we've talked to over 650 people in workshops and roundtables around the world from over 88 countries, and we've heard from over 1,200 people via public submissions. The consequences are that they've spotted a lot of issues and given us a huge amount of feedback. The rationale behind involving these people is that it should result in an institution that's stronger than if we had launched it on our own.

The approach you've set out for the oversight board has drawn comparisons to those of governmental structures. Yet international norms such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights already deal with issues such as freedom of expression, opinion and hate speech. Aren't there risks of reinventing the wheel or undermining existing mechanisms?

The approach we've taken is one that's informed by a number of global international norms, international laws and human rights. Facebook itself is rooted in free expression and Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. [Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.]

The exercise that we're engaged in as one that's fundamentally grounded in and informed by work that's been advancing over last century around these types of international norms. What we are trying to do now is understand how these norms apply in the context of Facebook, Instagram and the digital sphere as a whole.

How might the oversight board operate in countries with a value system at odds with the international norms and human rights you've referred to?

When we think about building out this board, the board can have no more power, can be delegated no more power, than Facebook holds, and Facebook's ability to operate is bound by the laws in place in the countries in which it operates.

The board is not and cannot be a substitute for local laws, it's a question of how you extend beyond it and how you interpret situations where laws do not yet apply.

In the last five years, Facebook's position with regards to the government regulation has shifted significantly in favour of more legislations. Looking beyond the oversight board, what would be an ideal regulatory environment for a company like Facebook to continue to be successful?

Mark Zuckerberg has called for regulation in four areas: one is in election protection, a second is in data portability, a third is in privacy and data protection issues, and then a fourth is to do with harmful content.

What we believe and this is embodied both in the oversight board and our call for regulation is that because we're a private company, we shouldn't hold the full responsibility for content decisions that extend to over two billion people around the world.

What we are calling for is greater accountability, greater oversight and greater transparency. It's also important that democratic institutions and civil society have a voice and perspective on these issues so we can make the digital sphere fairer and more just then it is today.

Senator Elizabeth Warren and Co-Founder of Facebook Chris Hughes have called for Facebook to be broken up, along with other big tech companies. Do you think that Facebook's dominant market position is a threat to competition?

Firstly, the market feels very competitive for us, we're in the middle of trying to figure out how to run the business, and secondly, the ability to deal with the types of concerns that people have articulated are not made easier by breaking up companies.

If you look at the types of issues around content moderation, around privacy, these require substantial systems and investments and technical insights that don't get stronger if you then try to fracture parts of a company.

What about today's start-ups which have to compete in an environment dominated by a handful of large tech companies - what challenges do you think a similar organization to Facebook would face if it was starting from scratch in 2019?

It's a good question. I think one of the major challenges would be how they deal with some of the government regulation that will come into play, the heightened expectations it will bring, and whether they'll have the right infrastructure in place to deal with that.

At the 2019 Chatham House Cyber Conference in June, Damian Collins MP spoke about two types of citizens: the 'remote-controlled' and the 'empowered', where the former is consuming information predetermined by algorithms, and the latter is able to access and navigate information free of algorithmic curation. Can you imagine a situation in which government regulation improves Facebook's algorithms?

There is going to be more regulation on just about every topic associated with technology and I believe more work needs to be done on these issues. However, one concern I have is that governments aren't necessarily in the best position to design and understand products. Moreover, they're not always well-versed in some of the really technical issues.

In the case of the algorithms, they're designed to bring people the content and information that they most want to see and the reason that those algorithms are in place is that they actually help people navigate a wide and vast array of different content.

LinkedIn recently announced that they have made changes to their algorithm to rank content related to a user's work interests above clickbait and viral content. What actions are Facebook prepared to take to ameliorate its newsfeed algorithms?

We are doing a lot of work to figure out down-ranking. If you look at misinformation for example, when third-party fact checkers come forward to inform us that a piece of content is fake or false, we essentially apply a speed limit making it far more difficult for that content to be seen.

urn:contentItem:5XDJ-3FW1-DXVP-V170-00000-00Bret Stephens: Elizabeth Warren is trying hard to lose your vote2019-11-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:26:37ZLexisNexisGUEST COLUMNSBret Stephens: Elizabeth Warren is trying hard to lose your vote

A decade ago, it was conventional wisdom that the world would soon start running low on oil and that the United States would henceforth be at the mercy of an inexorable trend. Then the fracking revolution came and the U.S. resumed its place as the world's top oil and natural gas producer.

The result: lower oil prices for American consumers, less dependence on petro-despots, a dramatic shift from coal to natural gas for electricity generation and hundreds of thousands of working-class jobs, including tens of thousands in swing states like Colorado and Pennsylvania.

Elizabeth Warren wants to kill all this.

You don't have to think that fracking is an unalloyed blessing to acknowledge its benefits. You might also argue that curbs on oil and gas production are needed both to preserve the environment and accelerate a transition to renewables. Fine.

Yet it takes a peculiar sort of political audacity to pledge, as the Massachusetts senator did last month, to "ban fracking everywhere." Warren also favors a ban on fossil-fuel exports and a "total moratorium" on new fossil-fuel leases on federal lands, which generate billions every year in federal and state revenue.

Native American tribes also got about $1 billion from those leases in 2018. Isn't the Warren campaign supposed to be about sticking it to richer Americans instead of poorer ones?

Or take health care: It may be ethically defensible for Warren to argue that Medicare for All is fairer than the current system. As an economic matter, she could be right that overall costs will come down. As a political matter, it isn't surprising that she has not been forthright about the middle-class tax increases her plan will require.

But what about the fact that Warren isn't merely proposing a dramatic change in the way 170 million or so Americans obtain health insurance? She is advocating the abolition of an entire industry, one that employs approximately 550,000 people. Whatever one thinks of health insurance companies, isn't it worth wondering what these half-million workers might do with themselves after being put out of work?

Then there's big tech, another industry Warren doesn't like and promises to "break up" by turning Facebook, Amazon and Google into regulated utilities. For this task, involving some 800,000 workers and companies with about $500 billion in revenues, she has ... a 1,700-word plan.

One wonders what Warren thinks might happen when things don't work out. Industries aren't assemblages of Lego blocks that can be taken apart and reassembled according to a clever new design. They are complex and evolving ecosystems, organized around scores of institutions, hundreds of laws, thousands of personalities and millions of relationships.

What will happen to the real human beings whose lives and careers will be upended or derailed while the mandarins of a Warren administration try to figure it out? Will President Warren have contingency plans for her ever-proliferating plans when things don't go according to plan?

Of course she won't. She won't because she can't; she can't because the central flaw of every economic plan is the plan itself.

That's the lesson of the 20th century, and it's why Warren's critics aren't totally off the mark in accusing her of being a socialist, not in intent but in mentality. Those with plans for everything prove only that they can't be trusted to plan for anything.

Voters may not yet see this, which is why Warren has risen in the polls. But they will, eventually, especially when they notice what the senator's plans entails for them. It's one thing for a Democratic politician to promise, as Barack Obama once did, to "spread the wealth around" – but only when "wealth" and "wealthy" mean the same thing. The Warren standard is to spread your wealth around whether you're wealthy or not.

In a recent column, my colleague David Brooks posed a difficult and necessary question: If the choice is Trump or Warren, what then? David's answer is that one would have to choose Warren, for the sake of democracy. Maybe he's right. But voters tend to place their personal interests ahead of their political ideals. And, other than Bernie Sanders, no Democratic candidate would more richly tempt Americans to vote the former than Warren.

For the sake of democracy, let's hope Democrats give America a better choice.

Bret Stephens is a columnist for The New York Times.

urn:contentItem:5WG2-74M1-JBHT-D37H-00000-00Brett Kavanaugh: Senate Committee to Take Key Vote Following Christine Blasey Ford's Testimony Live; The Ford-Kavanaugh Hearings Will Be Remembered as a Grotesque Display of Patriarchal Resentment; 7.5 Magnitude Earthquake Rocks Indonesia; Boeing Wins $9B Contract; Blue Origin To Supply Engines For Joint Venture; President Claire Underwood In New 'House of Cards' Trailer2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:26:37ZLexisNexisBrett Kavanaugh: Senate Committee to Take Key Vote Following Christine Blasey Ford's Testimony Live; The Ford-Kavanaugh Hearings Will Be Remembered as a Grotesque Display of Patriarchal Resentment; 7.5 Magnitude Earthquake Rocks Indonesia; Boeing Wins $9B Contract; Blue Origin To Supply Engines For Joint Venture; President Claire Underwood In New 'House of Cards' TrailerLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, September 28th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Time to vote. The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote this morning after the Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and his accuser Christine Blasey Ford testified on Capitol Hill yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. CHRISTINE BLASEY FORD, BRETT KAVANAUGH ACCUSER: I have been accused of acting out of partisan political motives. I'm an independently person and I am no one's pawn.

JUDGE BRETT KAVANAUGH, NOMINEE TO SERVE AS AN ASSOCIATE JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES: I will not be intimidated into withdrawing from this process. You've tried hard. You've given it your all. No one can question your efforts. But your coordinated and well- funded effort to destroy my good name and destroy my family will not drive me out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will have more of the emotional testimony coming up this morning. As of now, we know that Senators Bob Corker and Lindsey Graham have said that they will vote to confirm Brett Kavanaugh. More trouble for musk. The Securities and Exchange Commission filing suit against the Tesla CEO. The commission looks to bar him from running a public company ever again. Tesla stock is getting plummeted in the premarket. It is down 12- 1/2 percent right now.

Futures also showing a decline at the start of trading. We're at the lows of the morning. Things have been worsening throughout the morning. Dow Industrials down 108 points right now almost one half of one percent. S&P 500 is down a third of a percent and the NASDAQ with a 36 point decline down a half percent. This after a pretty good day yesterday. The major indices higher across the board at the close yesterday. NASDAQ best performer up 51 points.

We're at the end of the third quarter. This is the last trading day of the third quarter. The Dow is up almost nine percent for the quarter. The NASDAQ and the Standard & Poor's are up seven percent in the prior three months. In Europe this morning, weakness across the board, FT 100 down almost one percent. The CAC Quarante is down one and a quarter percent and the DAX Index in Germany at the low of the morning down 1-3/4 percent. Asian markets also mixed overnight but mostly higher.

The Nikkei Average best performer in Japan up 1-1/3 percent. Well, beware the bear. The Trump economy showing no signs of slowing down, solid employment numbers and a booming market all signs that the U.S. economy is doing well. One economist though is warning that a recession is on the horizon. He's here. Nouriel Roubini will join us. Joining me to break it all down right now is our own Dagen McDowell along with Kadena Group President Gary B. Smith, and the Hill Columnist, Fox News Contributor, Liz Peek.

Great to see you everybody this morning.

LIZ PEEK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to see you.

GARY SMITH, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR AND PRESIDENT, KADENA GROUP: Nice to be here.

(CROSSTALK)

Good to be here.

PERRY: -- the market is trying to figure out what to focus on, right? There are so much going on, right?

BARTIROMO: It sure is.

PEEK: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

SMITH: -- right now marching to its own drummer to be honest with you. All the news I think the markets held steady, you know, Maria knows I've been bullish since the get-go. I --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You've right. You've been right, Gary.

SMITH: I probably still am, yes.

BARTIROMO: Well, we got -- we got a market that has had a pretty good quarter and a backdrop, Dagen, as we talk about every day. That shows four percent plus economic growth. You have the GDP out yesterday 4.2 percent and earnings for the quarter is going to be up 22 percent.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Right. Maybe see -- we'll see three percent growth, three percent plus growth this calendar year. The first time that we will that will have happened and I keep saying it in more than a decade because it did not happen in any year during the Obama administration.

PEEK: And by the way we're the only major economy growing like that. So I mean it's sort of hard for investors to figure out where else to go.

MCDOWELL: One -- just one thing I want to call out yesterday. There was a lot to be appalled by coming from the Democrats. But I think the height of hypocrisy was Senator Richard Blumenthal lecturing Brett Kavanaugh about credibility talking about the legal principle that jurors can rule a witness to be completely untrue if they say one thing that is false. This is a man who lied about serving in Vietnam and then said yesterday that the accuser Blasey Ford had witnesses who could corroborate her story.

That's a lie.

PEEK: Yes. Which we know isn't true. They would have been -- they would have been presented to us before by the media for sure.

BARTIROMO: How does he get away with that just saying fallacies?

MCDOWELL: I -- I'm ashamed that I ever lived in Connecticut that that state would elect him to the Senate. I am appalled by that.

BARTIROMO: Well, we should forget that Jim Comey also had a thing or two to say about the same actually. He tweeted about it. And then Kim Strassel from the Journal tweeted out about him because no mention of the fact that she said she was afraid of flying and then, Mitchell, the sex crimes prosecutor came up with a list, a litany of places from Hawaii to Indonesia that she's been which was also pretty hypocritical.

PEEK: This is all about stalling. They just want to stall this process, you know, that's why -- repeated requests for an FBI investigation, etcetera, etcetera. It's so politically driven. It's really sad I think.

BARTIROMO: It sure is. It sure is. We'll get to all of that including the third quarter and get Gary's thoughts on what happens in fourth quarter coming up. Joining the conversation this morning Fox News Contributor and former Deputy Chief of Staff to President George W. Bush, Karl Rove is joining us this morning. Roubini Macro Associates CEO, Nouriel Roubini has a few things to say about that strength in the economy right now and what happens in the future, and "VARNEY & COMPANY's" own, Stuart Varney will weigh in as well.

Don't miss a moment of it. We got a big hour coming up. And we kick it off right here with this top story. Emotion, anguish, and reliving the past, dramatic testimony yesterday on Capitol Hill as Judge Brett Kavanaugh and Dr. Christine Blasey Ford made their case before the Senate Judiciary Committee. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

FORD: I don't have all the answers and I don't remember as much as I would like to. But the details that about that night that bring me here today are the ones I will never forget. They have been seared into my memory and it has haunted me episodically as an adult. Indelible in the hippocampus is the laughter. The laugh -- the uproarious laughter between the two and they're having fun at my expense.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Dr. Ford, with what degree of certainty do you believe Brett Kavanaugh assaulted you?

FORD: One hundred percent.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: One hundred percent?

KAVANAUGH: Less than two weeks ago, Dr. Ford publicly accused me of committing wrongdoing in an event more than 36 years ago when we were both in high school. I denied the allegation immediately, categorically, and unequivocally. This confirmation process has become a national disgrace. The constitution gives the Senate an important role in the confirmation process. But you have replaced advice and consent with search and destroy.

This whole two-week effort has been a calculated and orchestrated political hit fueled with apparent pent up anger about President Trump and the 2016 election. Fear that has been unfairly stoked about my judicial record, revenge on behalf of the Clintons, and millions of dollars in money from outside left-wing opposition groups. This is a circus.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now for White House reaction is White House Senior Adviser for the Strategic Communications, Mercedes Schlapp. Mercedes, good to see you this morning. Thanks very much for being here. Your reaction to what took place yesterday.

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, WHITE HOUSE DIRECTOR OF STRATEGIC COMMUNICATIONS: Look, it was a very long day and for Brett Kavanaugh, he spoke with great power very compelling, and very consistent in his story. He felt it was his moment to talk about where -- the facts and he did that. He brought out the facts. He brought out detail in terms of what -- of what his activities where the summer of 1982. But most importantly, Maria, he talked about how disgraceful this process has been with the Democrats.

I mean let's be real. OK. The Democrats from day one said they were going to do everything they could to stop Brett Kavanaugh. That was their goal. That was their focus. They called him evil. They called him a liar. They've even gone out to the fact that agreeing with a certain allegation that he could possibly be a gang raper. I mean it is a process that's become out of control. And with that, the Democrats had also mishandled this process.

They knew about this allegation for over 60 days, did nothing with it, waited until the last minute, and then started to drag Judge Kavanaugh's name through the mud. It has been something like I've never seen before in terms of trying to destroy someone who has served our country honorably, someone who has spent his -- most of his life in public service, who has worked for a former President, who has worked on the -- in the judicial system very successfully and like how he has mentioned, Maria, he's an independent judge.

He wants to do a good job. He's well qualified for this job, yet this has become a smear campaign, a character assassination of somehow who I know personally and someone who I think should be on the Supreme Court.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean throughout the hearing yesterday the testimony yesterday I think little by little people started to see through some of the games that were going on, on the left, and I wonder if you have heard from more people in the Senate in terms of the votes because we've already heard from Bob Corker who says he will vote yes toward Brett Kavanaugh. We know that Lindsey Graham will. I'm going to get to Lindsey Graham in a moment. But do you know of any -- do you think that the Senate has the votes for confirmation certainly from the committee standpoint?

SCHLAPP: You know, I feel we're in good shape. I think that we'll see what the Senate Judiciary Committee votes today what the vote is, but I feel like we're in very good shape. Obviously, Judge Kavanaugh was very transparent, very forthcoming, presented the facts, presented evidence against this allegation. With that being said, obviously, what Dr. Ford has experienced in her life is very saddening. But it's very clear that Judge Kavanaugh is innocent of this charges and he was willing to come forth day one when these accusations came out, day one, and yet, you know, here we are.

The GOP senator said we'll give her time. We even -- they even offered to go travel over to California. She said she wasn't even aware of that request, so you've got these Democrat political operative lawyers, Senator Feinstein who referred her to these layers and you're saying that this is not, you know, and there's people out there saying that this is not a political game --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: How much -- how normal is it for a ranking member of the -- of a major committee a judiciary committee to help a witness with her lawyer? I mean Senator Feinstein's office helped Blasey Ford obtain her lawyer.

SCHLAPP: Yes. I just never seen anything like this and this is why yesterday what it showed when the Democrats were trying to questioning Kavanaugh, it was very clear that they were going to do what they can to stop this man. It is their biggest nightmare that he is decided that he's not going to be intimidated that he's moving forward with this nomination, that he's not going to stand down for the past 10 days what that family has gone through is horrific. It should not be like this in America.

BARTIROMO: No, it shouldn't. And you're right to say America because that's what is at stake here. I mean we basically through due process out the window. That's not America. Senator Lindsey Graham said with a lot of people were thinking. He stood out on a Republican side giving this impassioned speech about how he has enough of what he calls a charade. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: What you want to do is destroy this guy's life, hold the seat open, and hope you win in 2020. You said that. When you see Sotomayor and Kagan, tell them that Lindsey said hello because I voted for them. I would never do to them what you've done to this guy. This is the most unethical sham since I've been in politics.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Kim Strassel writes this morning in the Journal a vote no if you vote no, you are legitimizing the most despicable thing I've seen in my time in politics as Lindsey Graham said it. A no vote now equals public approval of every unhanded tactic deployed by the left in recent weeks, do you think that outburst by Lindsey Graham helps Kavanaugh's confirmation or does it hurt it?

SCHLAPP: Look, I think Lindsey Graham was so incredibly powerful and at that moment, it was critical for Lindsey Graham to send a message to these Democrats. These Democrats who have tried to smear Kavanaugh's name and he stood up the same way Kavanaugh stood up for himself. They got tired. They're tired of being pushed by the left. They're tired by the lies of the left. They're tired of false media -- liberal media reporting where they would take any single possible accusation and try to pin it on Kavanaugh.

And so it was an incredibly important moment during the hearing for all of us because it represents that the Democrats are willing to go so low to destroy an incredibly reputable man and I find that to be disgusting. We should, Maria, we should not be at that point right now when it comes to confirming a Supreme Court justice.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, Liz Peek who's on the panel today pointed out the New York Times headlined today, and you speak about media. The New York Times says high stakes dual of tears and furry unfold in Senate. And here's the line, Blasey prays for courage, Trump applauds Kavanaugh's rebuttal. That's how the Times sums it up.

SCHLAPP: Right. And as Kavanaugh has said, this is about fairness. This is about both sides being heard. This is, you know, again, we look at Dr. Ford and maybe what she went through is incredibly difficult and we want to listen as Kavanaugh said, sexual harassment of any kind is horrific. But with that being said, when you go to the basics take out the emotion, look at the facts, look at the evidence.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SCHLAPP: As it was presented in a public hearing yesterday under oath. It was very clear that Kavanaugh had the facts that is very clear that you had those witnesses that basically had refuted her account. So, again, we got to look at the facts, put the emotions aside, and realize that Judge Kavanaugh is innocent and has been saying he's innocent from day one. He's got the facts to prove it.

BARTIROMO: Mercedes, thanks for joining us this morning.

SCHLAPP: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Mercedes Schlapp is at the White House. Coming up, trouble with Tesla. CEO Elon Musk faces an SEC lawsuit over his, "Funding secured tweet." He could lose his title as CEO and be barred from running a public company again. Then the Trump economy, we're firing on all cylinders that does not seem to be signs of a slowdown, but Nouriel Roubini is in the studio and he's warning of a recession on the horizon. He's here later this hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A lot happening in markets this morning, Tesla stock is down 12 percent after the Securities and Exchange Commission charged Elon Musk with fraud. Connell McShane is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Connell, good morning.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Maria. Yes, what a disaster for Tesla. I don't know that the SEC involvement as this came as a huge surprise to people. But the timing of the lawsuit being filed last night came a bit faster than some people thought it might come, and securities fraud allegations against Elon Musk does have that stock tumbling. The allegation here is that he Musk did not have the funding secured that he talked about to take the company private at $420 a share.

In fact, the SEC alleges that he never even discussed $420 with anybody that was -- that might provide that funding never really had his act together on it, and, you know, never discussed whether it was possible or not. But he did put a statement out last night. Musk was saying he was saddened and disappointed and talked about his integrity being his most important value, and says the facts will show he never compromised in any way.

Now, I will say this a couple of analyst comments that are of interest this morning, Citigroup just downgraded the stock a little while ago here before the open of trading. And also J.P. Morgan analyst had an interesting comment on Tesla shares, Maria, saying that this lawsuit could lead to a world where Tesla is valued on its fundamentals alone which would not be a good thing because as you know the stocks had been bid up over the years so much on a bet on one person. That person being Elon Musk.

BARTIROMO: That's right. Yes. I mean earlier we were talking about, you know, what happens to Apple with Steve Jobs gone. But Connell, that's why investors are reacting this morning and that's what you're seeing this morning. Gary B. Smith, your thoughts on this as the stock trades down, do you worry that should Elon Musk be forced out then this stock continues to plummet?

SMITH: Well, not only the stock. I see trouble on the horizon for the company. It's essentially been his vision like it has been with his private companies, the boring company, the, you know, what he does with the rockets and stuff like that, so I worry that the vision just like when Steve Jobs temporarily left Apple, they kind of plummeted. The whole vision and, you know, reason for existence for Tesla goes away.

BARTIROMO: But it came back and it's now a trillion-dollar company, Dagen.

We reported that perhaps there was a negotiation for a settlement that the SEC thought they had and then Elon's lawyers called them and said, "No, we're going to -- we're not going to go that route."

If you look at his statements following that tweet in August and since then he is really been making the case and in his mind e thought the funding was there. Of course, the SEC is saying not so fast but it really gets to this kind of the way Silicon Valley is operating.

You know, to be an entrepreneur like him, he has to kind of create his own reality. You know, he was told for many years he couldn't make electric cars cool, he's been able to do that. And we've seen him in recent years really pushback against regulators and, you know, let them do -- let him do the things he wants to do.

PEEK: Tim, it's Liz Peek. Good morning. What do you think about the succession issue here?

HIGGINS: Well that's a -- that's a -- it's a huge question. You know, basically the last two years or so it seen a huge exodus of top executives from the company, it's not an easy place to work. In recent months we've seen the top sales executive and the top -- and the engineering chief leave.

These are people that would have been maybe perhaps natural number twos, or people that could take the -- take the wheel if you will. But now they're gone and if the bench is not very deep.

BARTIROMO: Yes. By the way you just said he said he believe when he did the tweet that he had the funding, are you saying you believe the funding at $420 a share or was that some kind of a joke?

HIGGINS: Well, you know, he -- the complaints that we read there he basically said, well I got to do a premium on where the stock is, it's going to be at $419, you know, $420 that would be funny, maybe that would impress his girlfriend.

You know, in previous blog posts that he's put out, he's essentially made the case that, "Hey, had some meetings with the Saudi, of the Southern wealth fund. He thought that they wanted to help them take the company private, he could get something done. But, yes, the SEC is basically saying, "Hey, you didn't have this like locked in."

BARTIROMO: Right, of course. Tim, thanks very much for weighing in, we appreciate it. We sort of saw this coming, we reacted this way as soon as that tweet came out on this program I remember. Tim Higgins, thank you, from the Wall Street Journal.

Coming up, price to win, Boeing snagging a multibillion dollar Air Force contact, we'll tell you all about it when we come back.

And then technology transforms the way you travel, I'm sitting down with the CEO of Delta Airlines, Edward Bastian is here, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Friday, September 28th, your top stories right now, 6:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Showdown on Capitol Hill, Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, testifying in D.C., on a sexual misconduct allegations against Kavanaugh.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Of what degree of certainty do you believe Brett Kavanaugh assaulted you?

DR. CHRISTINE BLASEY FORD, KAVANAUGH ACCUSER: One hundred percent.

KAVANAUGH: I was not at the party described by Doctor Ford. This confirmation process has become a national disgrace.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will have much more on the fiery hearing yesterday, ahead of today's judiciary committee vote coming up. Already, we know, that Bob Corker said he will vote yes for Kavanagh.

Futures this morning, show the markets will open lower, Dow Industrials down 75 points, that's almost a third of a percent lower, S&P 500 down seven points, and the NASDAQ up 20 points, a quarter of a percent lower.

This after the markets were higher yesterday, Dow Industrials picking up 50 points at the close, 54 points higher, a quarter of a percent. The S&P was up a quarter of a percent and the NASDAQ with a 52-point move up, up two- thirds of one percent.

In Europe this morning, markets are lower, the FT-100, the CAC Quarante and the DAX Index down in the negative territory. The DAX Index in Germany down 1-1/2 percent right now.

Asian markets meanwhile, finishing mostly positive overnight, best performer there was Japan, up one and a third percent. In Korea, the KOSPI was down one half of a percent.

Sanctuary setback, a California judge deals a blow to the states' law, protecting illegal immigrants, and aiming high, the details behind Boeing's multi-billion-dollar contract with the U.S. Air Force.

Then, this, excitement on the gridiron, the Rams beat the Vikings in what could be the best game of the season. We've got all the highlights coming up, this morning.

Talk about a proposal in jeopardy, a contestant on the popular quiz show, Jeopardy, popping the question of his own. We have the adorable video, coming up, right here.

But first, our top story this half an hour, technology transforming travel, Delta Air Lines is preparing to launch the first biometric terminal in the country. Certain terminals at the Atlanta International Airport will be equipped with facial recognition technology from curb to gate, expected to become fully operational later this year.

Joining me right now in a FOX Business exclusive interview with the CEO of Delta Air Lines, Edward Bastian, Edward, it's great to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

EDWARD BASTIAN, CEO, DELTA AIR LINES: Thanks, Maria. It's great to be here.

BARTIROMO: This is really exciting stuff. Tell me what you are expecting and how this will work.

BASTIAN: Well, yes, we've transformed many parts of the travel experience for customers' stay, but the area that I think needs the most assistance right now is the airports, the airport environment going through security, with the gate and boarding process.

And we've been partnered with CBP, Customs and Border Patrol, to create a frictionless, paperless entry process, both, as you exit the country and as you -- as you return to the country for international travel.

BARTIROMO: Actually, this facial recognition has been successful for government because they are catching illegals coming in, as well.

BASTIAN: It's incredibly effective. It's the most efficient technology we've seen from a secure perspective and it also speeds the access through the airport quite quickly. It's great.

BARTIROMO: As you incorporate more technology into operations, what are the cost looking like? Is this going to impact expenses in a big way, next year?

BASTIAN: It's not. You know, we are investing heavily in technology because we are driving a lot of customer improvement, enhancements. It is driving revenue performance. It's driving some productivity enhancements. But, you know, a lot of this we are talking about now is basic infrastructure.

BARTIROMO: The company has been doing so well. Where does the growth come from out five years?

BASTIAN: Out five years, I think, it's going to be global. For the last few years, we focus largely on the U.S. marketplace, New York, L.A., Seattle, the coasts on both sides, international has been a little more challenging and it's good to see that demand is really strong, this year, international, as well as domestic.

And we've been growing internationally, all year, and I think the outlook for international growth is going to be quite promising.

BARTIROMO: You're right. I was taking with the CEO of Boeing, about the same topic, and he said a large percentage of the people in the world have never been on a plane.

BASTIAN: The U.S. marketplace is largely mature for air travel, you know, there's a lot new places to fly. We're building bigger airplanes and bigger airports, but not new markets to travel to.

So, the opportunity whether to Asia, Latin America, even into Europe, I think, is going to be the future and Africa, as well.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That's terrific, very exciting. So, the growth story will still be the U.S., but also incorporate a lot more potential international.

BASTIAN: Yes, the U.S. is always our home market, two-thirds of our revenue is in the majority of our profits are here in the U.S. But long- term, I'm thinking 5 years, I'm thinking 10, 20, 30 years from now. It's going to be international.

BARTIROMO: That's terrific. Tell me about the changes you're making to the fleet, this is also important, a lot of analysts, talking about this as the major growth proposal, as well.

BASTIAN: Right. With all the infrastructure constraints we have in the U.S., air traffic control and some of the other congestion issues, one of our strategies is to the deal with that is to build some larger airplanes so that we're not -- we don't have as much friction in the sky.

And so, you need larger airplanes, larger airports, but it's not going to be, you know, the air traffic control systems that we need built, are probably years away, in terms of being able to accommodate more travelers. There are no new landing slots here in LaGuardia or JFK. They're already at maximum capacity.

So, we need bigger capacity, and that's why we're putting bigger planes on our markets.

BARTIROMO: And it's more comfortable for passengers, as well, by the way.

BASTIAN: It's more comfortable, it's more fuel-efficient, it's more fuel effective, from an environmental perspective. The new planes that we're bringing in are about 20 percent more fuel-efficient than the planes that we're retiring. And it's a much better experience all around.

BARTIROMO: But how does that jive with what you have in terms of the airports right now? I mean, you look overseas, you've got beautiful, large airports, and then, like, you mentioned JFK and LaGuardia.

BASTIAN: Right.

BARTIROMO: Will they be able to accommodate these larger planes?

BASTIAN: They will. We're investing in the airports, as well. We've got the biggest investment project in our history, going on right now at LaGuardia Airport. It is $3-1/2 billion rebuild of LaGuardia. It's going to take several years to get done. We're going to be opening the first concourse in the next 18 months.

So, it's not that far away. But we have similar projects going in L.A. We're building a brand new airport, LAX, new international facility in Seattle, brand new airport in Salt Lake City. We've just completed a big modernization in Atlanta.

So, $12 billion of airport infrastructure that Delta is putting in, in place, in the U.S. and, you know, five years from now, I think we're going to have some great airports.

BARTIROMO: That's fantastic because -- and that infrastructure move could be a partnership government, as well as private sector, right?

BASTIAN: We do work effectively -- with our -- with our municipalities, with our local governments, absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you, earlier this week, the House passed legislation that would establish a minimum standard for a leg room on commercial flights. The Bill now moves to the Senate. If it passes in the Senate, how would the changes impact Delta? Because it seems like you are doing exactly what they are just talking about in Washington.

BASTIAN: We are doing exactly what they're talking about. And we're no concerned. It's -- the FAA Bill is instructed the DOT to look after the safety, relative to seat pitch of the airlines. We're confident that our airplanes -- because we haven't touched our seat pitch in years.

At Delta, our product standards have -- are not being compromised. We don't think it's going to be an issue for Delta, and I doubt it's going to be an issue for the industry.

BARTIROMO: That's great. All good news here, and yet, just recently, your experience, a tough day, now you have a technical glitch, caused a nationwide grounding on Tuesday. There were only three cancellations, amazingly.

Delta had to delay more than 660 flights, though, according to FlightAware. A lot of people were talking about how the Delta folks really responded well bringing Dunkin' Donuts to people, helping them get through it. Nobody likes travel, hell. But tell us what happened that day and how the firm responded.

BASTIAN: We had a glitch in some of our departure technology that allows us to push our planes back from the gate. It caused about a 30-minute ground stop for systems, so it did cause some disruption, as you say, it was minimal, relative to cancellations and as well as delays.

You know, one of the things that we've been investing also and heavily, is technology and infrastructure, and the ability to respond when we have some of these glitches, if technologies are like flood, and we've got to create continued improvement there to improve the processing.

But one of the things I was most proud of, is when you look at our performance that day, relative to our major competitors, we still outperformed our major competitors even with that small glitch, so team did a great job.

BARTIROMO: They seem to have done a great job, you're right. I mean, you -- this is the way of life, you're going to have glitches in the airline business, right?

BASTIAN: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: It's about how you respond to it.

BASTIAN: Yes. I would have said several years ago, that could have been two, three, four hours to respond, to get it done. We got it done actually, in 26 minutes. It was pretty -- it was pretty quick.

BARTIROMO: And I know that when I am on a Delta flight, there you are in the video. I mean, you are right, front and center. You want the employees, as well as the customers to know the buck stops with you.

BASTIAN: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: So let me ask you your take on what we're talking about in terms of the intersection of business and social media. We got this growing number of CEOs turning to the online platforms, most recently, the CEO of Tesla, obviously, with this tweet.

Now, the SCC is looking into it and actually bringing a lawsuit. What's your take on going that far in terms of tweeting, as a CEO of a public company?

BASTIAN: Well, I don't tweet. That's one of the things I have stayed away, though, I am on social media. You know, I think today's customers and especially the next generation of customers, look for leadership, and they're looking for leadership in Washington. They're looking for leadership from their products, from the companies, and services that they buy from.

And I don't think you can avoid being visible, as you say, you have customers want to know where you stand on issues that affect your business and affects your employees, and sometimes you have to take -- come out and take a stand, but we try to be careful with where we position ourselves, because the brand is incredibly important to us.

BARTIROMO: That's all you have. You got your reputation. Let me end on the backdrop in terms of the climate today. Ed, how do bookings look, what are you expecting in terms of the economy going into 2019?

BASTIAN: We are very optimistic. We just finished the strongest summer travel season in our history. We expect to carry 200 million passengers this year, largest in our history, and the (INAUDIBLE) is quite positive. And the good thing, Maria, it's not just U.S. international. It's also business and leisure, so all sectors of our business are performing very, very well.

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting to raise prices as a result of oil prices are?

BASTIAN: Well, you have to cover the cost and all prices have been a significant increase for us, so we are looking at about $2 billion-dollar or higher fuel bill this year, than last year. But despite that, our overall profit level for this year is going to be roughly the same as it was last year.

So, we've been able to cover the cost in various ways, some price increases have gone into effect, but also a lot of productivity and a lot of improvements in our network that's also allowed us to drive that efficiency.

BARTIROMO: Do you believe this narrative that the broad economic backdrop slows down quite a bit, within the next two years going into 2020?

BASTIAN: Yes, we haven't seen it. You read the headlines. You would anticipate that with tariffs and the rhetoric that is going on. Our international business is the strongest I've seen in years, so we're continuing to serve that demand and we're optimistic.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations, Edward, great to see you.

BASTIAN: Thanks, Maria. Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Edward Bastian there, as the CEO at Delta Air Lines. Coming up, blast off, Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin, just landed a major rocket deal. We'll tell you all about it. Plus, what is, I do? One Jeopardy contestant winning big, on-air marriage proposal, we've got the moments, stay with us, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are lower right now. Futures indicating a decline of about 60 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, about a quarter of a percent lower. This, of course, the final trading day of the third quarter. We are looking at a, not bad quarter, but we're going to give you all the numbers coming up. First, though, a city in California successfully challenges the state's immigration law. Lauren Simonetti with the details and headlines now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: An Orange County judge ruled that California's so-called sanctuary state law is unconstitutional. The judge saying, the law violates the rights of charter city saying they should be allowed to police themselves. The City of Huntington Beach had challenged the law arguing it infringes on local government authority. The ruling makes Huntington Beach and all of California's 121 charter cities exempt from complying with that law.

Boeing landing a $9 billion contract with the Air Force. Boeing will build hundreds of new training jets to replace the Air Force's current fleet which is 57 years old. Meanwhile, this: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos's startup, has been tapped to supply engines for a joint venture between Boeing and Lockheed Martin. That venture sends U.S. military and spy satellite into outer space. Shares of Boeing, you take a look at the numbers of the year, up 24 percent, and shares of Lockheed Martin up 70 percent. Now, you know.

And what is yes? One "Jeopardy" contestant may have come in second place but he walked away a big winner.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL PASCUZZI, JEOPARDY CONTESTANT: I just wanted to say one quick thing and ask Maria Shafer right there if she would make me a winner today and marry me.

MARIA SHAFER, GIRLFRIEND OF MICHAEL PASCUZZI: That would be what is. yes?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: He popped the question on the air with a little help from the host, Alex Trebek. Trebek even joked that she said yes too quickly before he had the chance to say we'll have the answer right after the commercial break.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: And what happened to his beard? Didn't he have a beard for a while? Trebek?

BARTIROMO: I missed that. I missed that. OK. Yes, I think you're right. Thank you, Lauren. Coming up, a Thursday night thriller. The Rams beating the Vikings in what could be the best game of the season. We've got all the highlight in sports right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, if Thursday wasn't wild enough, it was a wild start to Thursday night football on Fox, as well. Jared Max, the L.A. Rams are for real.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: They are. What an exciting game, Maria. Over 1000 years of offense in a shootout between the Rams and Vikings. And it was a career night for Ram's second-year quarterback Jared Goff. In the first half alone, Goff threw for 251 yards and four touchdowns. Cooper Cup corralled a pair of scores, 162 yards of receiving at all. Now, while Minnesota Q.B., Kirk Cousins threw for over 400 yards and three scores, he was stripped of the ball with just over two minutes to play. The Rams win 38-31. Goff with the perfect passer rating for the 4-0 Rams. L.A. was for real. Minnesota suffered since the second loss.

Every two years, the best golfers from the United States play the best from Europe -- it's the Ryder Cup, underway today in Paris. Now, four matches of four balls this morning, three of the four matches are all square late, including Tiger Woods and Patrick Reid, and their match against Tommy Fleetwood and Francesco Molinari. The only one of the morning matches is complete, Dustin Johnson and Ricky Fowler win their match 4-2. After the morning matches are complete, we'll find out who was going to be playing this afternoon.

45 years since George Foreman knocked out Joe Frazier in the first fight ever broadcast on HBO the premier cable network is stepping out of the ring. In boxing terms, HBO Sports will throw the towel in after 2018. They say, "We will be pivoting away from programming live boxing, we'll remain open to looking at events that fit our programming -- this could include boxing not just for the foreseeable future. We're deeply indebted to the many courageous fighters whose careers we were privileged to cover." No fight after October 27th on HBO schedule.

Question: Is the NBA about to monetize on, maybe, its inability of its product to not hold enough interest for four quarters of the game? The NBA Sports announced beginning this season, fans will be able to purchase the fourth quarters of out of market games -- $1.99. You can buy it at any point after the third quarter. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver says, "The new micro transaction offerings on the NBA League Pass will deliver more customized experiences to meet the needs of NBA fans instead of waiting to watch the highlights after game, fans will enjoy a portion of the game in real time. I don't know who's tuning in to see any portion of an NBA game except for the final minute or two. Even gamblers who might bet on just, you know, the first half of the game.

SMITH: Jared, golf question: Do you think Tiger Woods is now the sports story of the year?

MAX: Yes, yes. That wim at the tour championship.

BARTIROMO: Big comeback.

MAX: And then, we said for months here that as his comeback was building, I know I kept saying it's he's already there. The win is going to happen. He put all the pieces of his game together and was just fantastic.

SMITH: The highest ratings of any tournament other than (INAUDIBLE) this year?

BARTIROMO: That was amazing.

MAX: Outside of Masters and the PGA championship final round, that final round of the tour championship, 206 percent higher ratings than the year before. And that was the highest final round.

PEEK: Boy, that will make PGA happy.

MAX: Sports fans should be happy -- golf. You look at these great golfers who came around since Tiger had left for a while. This is great.

BARTIROMO: Good stuff. Jared, thank you.

MAX: Happy Friday.

BARTIROMO: Have a great weekend, Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or on Sirius Radio XM 115. Still ahead, supplies of Kentucky Bourbon at the highest level in more than four decades; why trade is partly to blame for all those supplies, next hour right on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday. It is Friday, September 28th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Fireworks on Capitol Hill. The Senate Judiciary Committee set to vote this morning on --

END

urn:contentItem:5TD8-8FG1-JBHT-D424-00000-00Brett Kavanaugh: Senate Committee to Take Key Vote Following Christine Blasey Ford's Testimony Live; The Ford-Kavanaugh Hearings Will Be Remembered as a Grotesque Display of Patriarchal Resentment; 7.5 Magnitude Earthquake Rocks Indonesia; Boeing Wins $9B Contract; Blue Origin To Supply Engines For Joint Venture; President Claire Underwood In New 'House of Cards' Trailer2018-09-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:26:38ZLexisNexisBrett Kavanaugh: Senate Committee to Take Key Vote Following Christine Blasey Ford's Testimony Live; The Ford-Kavanaugh Hearings Will Be Remembered as a Grotesque Display of Patriarchal Resentment; 7.5 Magnitude Earthquake Rocks Indonesia; Boeing Wins $9B Contract; Blue Origin To Supply Engines For Joint Venture; President Claire Underwood In New 'House of Cards' TrailerLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, September 28th, your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Time to vote. The Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote this morning after the Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh and his accuser Christine Blasey Ford testified on Capitol Hill yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. CHRISTINE BLASEY FORD, BRETT KAVANAUGH ACCUSER: I have been accused of acting out of partisan political motives. I'm an independently person and I am no one's pawn.

But I do think there's a number of examples now where maybe Elon, by his own admission, probably should get a little more sleep and probably should be a little more careful before he tweets.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean a lot of discussion this morning about what happens to Tesla if Elon Musk is not there. I mean he's, you know, being sued by the SEC. I'm glad Google is going to be in Washington today to talk about what they're doing. And think about what the role of these big platforms is. And as I say, it's not surprising that there's more of a backlash against big tech or backlash against Silicon Valley. I predicted it almost three years ago.

I wrote the book, "The Third Wave" because as these platforms become bigger and have more impact and in some cases -- in the face of Facebook maybe even influence the election -- it's not surprising there's nor scrutiny. I think there will be more entrepreneurs in this third wave of the Internet when you're dealing with health care and food and other smart cities.

That somewhat, some of the challenges we have right now including on the -- on the political front are going to worsen. There are a lot of people in this country -- the majority of the country by some estimates are anxious and fearful of the future. They don't view innovation as a good thing or disruption as a good thing. They view it as a bad thing. It's going to end up potentially destroying their jobs or their communities.

So, we need to make sure we understand that startups play a critical role. We need to level the playing field so everybody, everywhere really has a shot at the American dream. And we're creating jobs all across the country, not just on the coast.

BARTIROMO: You're right. So, you just say three states get the majority of what, private equity?

BARTIROMO: Are you expecting to raise prices as a result of oil prices are?

BASTIAN: Well, you have to cover the cost and all prices have been a significant increase for us, so we are looking at about $2 billion-dollar or higher fuel bill this year, than last year. But despite that, our overall profit level for this year is going to be roughly the same as it was last year.

So, we've been able to cover the cost in various ways, some price increases have gone into effect, but also a lot of productivity and a lot of improvements in our network that's also allowed us to drive that efficiency.

BARTIROMO: Do you believe this narrative that the broad economic backdrop slows down quite a bit, within the next two years going into 2020?

BASTIAN: Yes, we haven't seen it. You read the headlines. You would anticipate that with tariffs and the rhetoric that is going on. Our international business is the strongest I've seen in years, so we're continuing to serve that demand and we're optimistic.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations, Edward, great to see you.

BASTIAN: Thanks, Maria. Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Edward Bastian there, as the CEO at Delta Air Lines. Coming up, blast off, Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin, just landed a major rocket deal. We'll tell you all about it. Plus, what is, I do? One Jeopardy contestant winning big, on-air marriage proposal, we've got the moments, stay with us, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are lower right now. Futures indicating a decline of about 60 points on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, about a quarter of a percent lower. This, of course, the final trading day of the third quarter. We are looking at a, not bad quarter, but we're going to give you all the numbers coming up. First, though, a city in California successfully challenges the state's immigration law. Lauren Simonetti with the details and headlines now, Lauren.

SIMONETTI: An Orange County judge ruled that California's so-called sanctuary state law is unconstitutional. The judge saying, the law violates the rights of charter city saying they should be allowed to police themselves. The City of Huntington Beach had challenged the law arguing it infringes on local government authority. The ruling makes Huntington Beach and all of California's 121 charter cities exempt from complying with that law.

Boeing landing a $9 billion contract with the Air Force. Boeing will build hundreds of new training jets to replace the Air Force's current fleet which is 57 years old. Meanwhile, this: Blue Origin, Jeff Bezos's startup, has been tapped to supply engines for a joint venture between Boeing and Lockheed Martin. That venture sends U.S. military and spy satellite into outer space. Shares of Boeing, you take a look at the numbers of the year, up 24 percent, and shares of Lockheed Martin up 70 percent. Now, you know.

And what is yes? One "Jeopardy" contestant may have come in second place but he walked away a big winner.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL PASCUZZI, JEOPARDY CONTESTANT: I just wanted to say one quick thing and ask Maria Shafer right there if she would make me a winner today and marry me.

MARIA SHAFER, GIRLFRIEND OF MICHAEL PASCUZZI: That would be what is. yes?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SIMONETTI: He popped the question on the air with a little help from the host, Alex Trebek. Trebek even joked that she said yes too quickly before he had the chance to say we'll have the answer right after the commercial break.

(LAUGHTER)

SIMONETTI: And what happened to his beard? Didn't he have a beard for a while? Trebek?

BARTIROMO: I missed that. I missed that. OK. Yes, I think you're right. Thank you, Lauren. Coming up, a Thursday night thriller. The Rams beating the Vikings in what could be the best game of the season. We've got all the highlight in sports right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, if Thursday wasn't wild enough, it was a wild start to Thursday night football on Fox, as well. Jared Max, the L.A. Rams are for real.

JARED MAX, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK SPORTS REPORTER: They are. What an exciting game, Maria. Over 1000 years of offense in a shootout between the Rams and Vikings. And it was a career night for Ram's second-year quarterback Jared Goff. In the first half alone, Goff threw for 251 yards and four touchdowns. Cooper Cup corralled a pair of scores, 162 yards of receiving at all. Now, while Minnesota Q.B., Kirk Cousins threw for over 400 yards and three scores, he was stripped of the ball with just over two minutes to play. The Rams win 38-31. Goff with the perfect passer rating for the 4-0 Rams. L.A. was for real. Minnesota suffered since the second loss.

Every two years, the best golfers from the United States play the best from Europe -- it's the Ryder Cup, underway today in Paris. Now, four matches of four balls this morning, three of the four matches are all square late, including Tiger Woods and Patrick Reid, and their match against Tommy Fleetwood and Francesco Molinari. The only one of the morning matches is complete, Dustin Johnson and Ricky Fowler win their match 4-2. After the morning matches are complete, we'll find out who was going to be playing this afternoon.

45 years since George Foreman knocked out Joe Frazier in the first fight ever broadcast on HBO the premier cable network is stepping out of the ring. In boxing terms, HBO Sports will throw the towel in after 2018. They say, "We will be pivoting away from programming live boxing, we'll remain open to looking at events that fit our programming -- this could include boxing not just for the foreseeable future. We're deeply indebted to the many courageous fighters whose careers we were privileged to cover." No fight after October 27th on HBO schedule.

Question: Is the NBA about to monetize on, maybe, its inability of its product to not hold enough interest for four quarters of the game? The NBA Sports announced beginning this season, fans will be able to purchase the fourth quarters of out of market games -- $1.99. You can buy it at any point after the third quarter. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver says, "The new micro transaction offerings on the NBA League Pass will deliver more customized experiences to meet the needs of NBA fans instead of waiting to watch the highlights after game, fans will enjoy a portion of the game in real time. I don't know who's tuning in to see any portion of an NBA game except for the final minute or two. Even gamblers who might bet on just, you know, the first half of the game.

SMITH: Jared, golf question: Do you think Tiger Woods is now the sports story of the year?

MAX: Yes, yes. That wim at the tour championship.

BARTIROMO: Big comeback.

MAX: And then, we said for months here that as his comeback was building, I know I kept saying it's he's already there. The win is going to happen. He put all the pieces of his game together and was just fantastic.

SMITH: The highest ratings of any tournament other than (INAUDIBLE) this year?

BARTIROMO: That was amazing.

MAX: Outside of Masters and the PGA championship final round, that final round of the tour championship, 206 percent higher ratings than the year before. And that was the highest final round.

PEEK: Boy, that will make PGA happy.

MAX: Sports fans should be happy -- golf. You look at these great golfers who came around since Tiger had left for a while. This is great.

BARTIROMO: Good stuff. Jared, thank you.

MAX: Happy Friday.

BARTIROMO: Have a great weekend, Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports on Fox News Headlines 24/7 or on Sirius Radio XM 115. Still ahead, supplies of Kentucky Bourbon at the highest level in more than four decades; why trade is partly to blame for all those supplies, next hour right on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday. It is Friday, September 28th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Fireworks on Capitol Hill. The Senate Judiciary Committee set to vote this morning on --

END
